Förutom allvarliga fall av meningit och blodförgiftning är pneumokocker också en vanlig orsak till lunginflammation, bihåleinflammation och öroninflammation hos barn. Bakterien är indelad i olika serotyper som varierar i förekomst.
can_be_vaccinated: Det finns flera typer av vacciner mot pneumokocksjukdom som skyddar mot ett antal av de vanligaste pneumokocktyperna.
Vaccination ingår i det danska barndvaccinationsprogrammet och ges som 3 doser vid 3, 5 och 12 månaders ålder.
Dessutom rekommenderar hälsomyndigheterna vaccination för ett antal personer med ökad risk för allvarlig pneumokocksjukdom.
occurrence: Det är vanligt att bära pneumokocker i nasofarynx utan att bli sjuk. Bärarskap är särskilt vanligt bland barn.
source: Sprids via andningssekret.

polio.title: Polio
polio.description: Polio är en extremt smittsam virussjukdom som kan orsaka meningit och förlamning och kan vara livshotande. Vaccination ingår i det danska barndvaccinationsprogrammet.
what_is: Polio (poliomyelit) är en smittsam virussjukdom. Över 90 % av alla fall är utan symtom.

Tidiga symtom liknar vanlig influensa, såsom feber, ont i halsen och allmän sjukdomskänsla. För de flesta slutar sjukdomen här, men i 1–5 % av fallen angriper viruset nervsystemet som meningit med mer allvarliga symtom och kan vara livshotande om det förlamar andningsmusklerna.
Mindre än 1 % av alla polioinfektioner orsakar förlamning. Många år efter den akuta fasen kan patienter som haft förlamning fortfarande uppleva betydande långsiktiga effekter.
can_be_vaccinated: Poliovaccination ingår i det nationella vaccinationsprogrammet.
Vaccination erbjuds som en del av barnprogrammet vid 3, 5 och 12 månader, med en booster/revaccination när barnet är 5 år.

Det finns ett fåtal länder där poliovirus fortfarande förekommer. Det kan finnas krav på polio revaccination vid resa till dessa länder. Prata med din läkare eller vaccinationsklinik om de senaste rekommendationerna kring polio i samband med din resa.
occurrence: Det finns hopp om att utrota polio helt, men poliovirus cirkulerar fortfarande i ett fåtal länder.
source: Viruset sprids främst från person till person eller via infekterad mat eller dryck. Polio är extremt smittsamt, men i de flesta fall utan symtom.

rabies.title: Rabies
rabies.description: En virussjukdom som påverkar centrala nervsystemet och så småningom orsakar encefalit och död. Rabies sprids via saliv från ett infekterat djur. Vaccination ingår inte i det nationella barndvaccinationsprogrammet.
what_is: Rabies är en virussjukdom som påverkar centrala nervsystemet och så småningom orsakar encefalit och död. Sjukdomen överförs till människor via saliv från ett infekterat djur, vanligtvis genom ett bett eller när saliv kommer i kontakt med öppna sår eller slemhinnor genom att djuret slickar dem.
Symtom uppträder vanligtvis några veckor till flera månader efter ett bett. Tidiga symtom inkluderar feber, huvudvärk och allmän sjukdomskänsla, följt av symtom på encefalit, t.ex. hallucinationer.
Infekterade personer kan också reagera på vatten och få kramper med andnings- och sväljsvårigheter, beskrivet som hydrofobi. Förlamning kan också uppstå.
När symtomen väl har uppstått kan rabies inte botas och leder till döden, men sjukdomen kan förebyggas med vaccination (eventuellt kombinerat med immunoglobulin).
can_be_vaccinated: Du måste ordna vaccination mot rabies själv, eftersom den inte ingår i det nationella vaccinationsprogrammet.

Behovet av vaccination före exponering bedöms individuellt. Det är extremt viktigt att du ändå söker medicinsk hjälp omedelbart efter exponering för att få ytterligare vaccinationer för att förebygga sjukdomen, även om du tidigare har vaccinerats.

Om du blir biten eller utsatt för saliv, till exempel av ett djur som kan vara infekterat med rabies, är det viktigt att noggrant tvätta såret och söka medicinsk hjälp omedelbart – även om du tidigare har vaccinerats, eftersom du behöver ytterligare vaccinationer för att förebygga sjukdomen.

Det finns också förebyggande behandling som kan påbörjas efter exponering, även utan tidigare vaccination. Den måste påbörjas omedelbart efter bettet för att motverka den dödliga sjukdomen och består av både vaccinationer och rabiesimmunoglobulininjektioner.

Eftersom rabiesvirus kan finnas i en persons vävnad långt innan symtomen börjar är det viktigt att resenärer som blivit bitna av ett djur som kan vara infekterat med rabies fullföljer den förebyggande behandlingen, även om lång tid har gått sedan bettet.
Prata med din läkare om risken för rabies under din resa och om du bör vaccineras före resan samt hur du ska agera vid exponering.
occurrence: Rabies förekommer över hela världen, och det uppskattas att över 55 000 människor, främst i Afrika och Asien, dör av sjukdomen varje år. I Danmark förekommer rabies i fladdermöss.
source: Bett eller slick från ett infekterat djur, där saliv kommer in i såret eller slemhinnor.

rotavirus.title: Rotavirus
rotavirus.description: Ett virus som orsakar diarré som kan vara allvarlig hos spädbarn och små barn, särskilt mellan 6 och 18 månader. Vaccination ingår inte i Danmarks nationella vaccinationsprogram för barn.
what_is: Rotavirus orsakar sjukdom med diarré och kräkningar, särskilt hos barn i åldern 6 till 18 månader. Hos vuxna är sjukdomen mindre vanlig och mycket mildare och kortare. Sjukdomen är förknippad med risk för uttorkning, särskilt hos spädbarn, vilket kan vara allvarligt (livshotande) och kräva sjukhusvård med intravenös vätskebehandling.

Symtom på rotavirusinfektion inkluderar vattnig diarré, kräkningar och ibland feber, vilket tillsammans snabbt kan leda till vätskeförlust. Symtomen varar vanligtvis i cirka fem dagar men kan vara betydligt längre hos spädbarn.
Inkuberingsperioden är ett par dagar och stora mängder virus utsöndras i avföringen i ungefär en vecka.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination ingår inte i Danmarks nationella vaccinationsprogram för barn.
Vacciner mot rotavirus finns tillgängliga. Beroende på produkt tas vaccinet oralt i två eller tre doser.
occurrence: Rotavirus är en mycket vanlig orsak till sjukdom med diarré och kräkningar hos barn både i Danmark och världen över. Rotavirus är mycket smittsamt och nästan alla barn har blivit smittade vid 2–3 års ålder.
Sjukdomen är säsongsbunden – i Danmark vanligtvis december till april.
I Danmark är rotavirusrelaterade dödsfall extremt sällsynta, men enligt WHO:s beräkningar fanns det omkring 453 000 dödsfall bland barn 2008 på grund av rotavirusrelaterad gastroenterit.
source: Direkt eller indirekt intag av avföring från smittade personer.
Fysisk kontakt med andra människor
Smitta via leksaker och dörrhandtag
Intag av förorenad mat eller dryck.

rubella.title: Röda hund
rubella.description: En smittsam virussjukdom som vanligtvis är mild men kan vara allvarlig för gravida kvinnor på grund av hög risk för fosterskador om man smittas tidigt i graviditeten. MPR-vaccination ingår i det nationella vaccinationsprogrammet för barn.
what_is: Röda hund är en smittsam sjukdom som orsakas av ett virus. Vanliga symtom inkluderar svullna lymfkörtlar, feber, huvudvärk, rödaktig utslag och ledvärk, men sjukdomen kan också vara asymtomatisk.
Hos gravida kvinnor kan röda hund orsaka missfall eller allvarliga fosterskador, särskilt tidigt i graviditeten.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccinet mot röda hund ingår i det nationella vaccinationsprogrammet för barn. MPR-vaccinet, som inkluderar vaccination mot röda hund, ger även skydd mot mässling och påssjuka. Vaccination ges vid 15 månader och 4 år (tidigare vid 12 år).

Vuxna kvinnor som inte är vaccinerade (eller inte har haft sjukdomen) rekommenderas vaccination på grund av risken för allvarliga fosterskador under graviditet och erbjuds gratis vaccination. Vaccinet får inte ges till gravida kvinnor.
occurrence: Röda hund är nästan utrotat i Danmark tack vare vaccination. Sjukdomen förekommer fortfarande på många håll i världen – utbrott kan även förekomma i Europa.
source: Luftburen smitta via inandning av andningssekret (droppar) från en smittad person.
Prata med din läkare om vaccination

chickenpox.title: Vattkoppor
chickenpox.description: En sjukdom som orsakas av ett virus. I Danmark blir de flesta smittade som barn. Viruset kan senare orsaka bältros hos personer som har haft vattkoppor. Vaccination ingår inte i Danmarks nationella vaccinationsprogram för barn.
what_is: Vattkoppor är en mycket vanlig barnsjukdom som orsakas av varicella-zosterviruset. Risken för komplikationer är högre hos vuxna och personer med nedsatt immunförsvar än hos friska barn. Under graviditet kan sjukdomen orsaka komplikationer för modern och är allvarlig för nyfödda om modern smittas nära förlossningen. Det finns också en liten risk för fosterskador. För personer med nedsatt immunförsvar kan vattkoppor vara allvarliga och till och med livshotande.
Vattkoppor kan orsaka komplikationer som lunginflammation, encefalit och bakteriell hudinfektion.

Symtomen på vattkoppor uppträder 10–20 dagar efter smitta. Under denna period förökar sig viruset först i luftvägarna och sprids sedan till resten av kroppen, vilket orsakar utslag. Innan utslagen uppträder kan du få lätt feber och symtom som vid en vanlig förkylning. Utslagen börjar som röda fläckar som sedan växer och utvecklas till blåsor. Blåsfasen följs av en fas med torr hud och sårskorpor medan blåsorna läker om ingen bakterieinfektion utvecklas. Feber kan också förekomma, särskilt om det finns många blåsor.

Viruset sprids lätt genom luften och små droppar av vätska från blåsorna. Efter tillfrisknande förblir viruset vilande i nervceller och kan reaktiveras senare i livet och orsaka bältros. Blåsorna vid bältros innehåller också smittsamt virus och kan därför smitta icke-immuna personer med vattkoppor.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination ingår inte i Danmarks nationella vaccinationsprogram för barn.

Vacciner mot vattkoppor finns tillgängliga i Danmark, vanligtvis för personer med särskilda riskfaktorer – inklusive kvinnor i barnafödande ålder som inte har haft vattkoppor (men vaccinet får inte ges till gravida kvinnor och graviditet bör undvikas en tid efter vaccination).
Prata med din läkare om huruvida du bör vaccineras.
Du kan försöka undvika smitta genom att undvika kontakt med personer som har symtom. För vissa riskgrupper kan läkaren besluta att ge immunoglobulin efter exponering.
occurrence: Det uppskattas att 98 % av vuxna danskar som vuxit upp i Danmark har haft vattkoppor. Sjukdomen är mindre vanlig i tropiska områden, där en större andel vuxna inte har haft den.
source: Smitta sker luftburet från person till person via andningssekret och små droppar av vätska från blåsor
Direkt kontakt med vätska från blåsor på huden

tetanus.title: Stelkramp
tetanus.description: En sjukdom orsakad av en bakterie som vanligtvis finns i jord. Kombinationsvaccin som även skyddar mot stelkramp ingår i det nationella vaccinationsprogrammet för barn.
what_is: Stelkramp är en bakteriell sjukdom med symtom som huvudvärk, muskelstelhet och svåra muskelkramper. Bakterien finns normalt i jord. Den tränger in genom ett sår eller skrapa i huden och börjar producera toxiner som orsakar muskelkontraktioner och ett kramp-tillstånd som kan vara livshotande.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination mot stelkramp ingår i det nationella vaccinationsprogrammet för barn.
Vaccination mot stelkramp ges i tre doser vid 3, 5 och 12 månader. En enkel boosterdos ges när barnet fyller 5 år. Efterföljande boostervaccination ingår inte som en del av programmet i sig.
SSI rekommenderar att alla revaccineras mot difteri och stelkramp vart 10:e år.
Revaccination rekommenderas också vid utlandsresor om senaste vaccinationen var mer än 10 år sedan.
Vaccination ger det viktigaste skyddet. För att undvika infektion, se till att öppna sår, skrapsår och nötningar är ordentligt skyddade från kontakt med jord, sand och andra potentiella smittkällor.
occurrence: Vaccinationer, förbättrad hygien och medicin har kraftigt minskat antalet fall av stelkramp i västvärlden. I Danmark förekommer sjukdomen inte hos spädbarn, men i utvecklingsländer är den fortfarande en vanlig dödsorsak bland små barn. WHO uppskattade att 50 000 spädbarn dog av stelkramp 2008.
source: Infekterad jord i öppna sår.

tuberculosis.title: Tuberkulos
tuberculosis.description: En smittsam och potentiellt dödlig bakteriesjukdom som är utbredd världen över.
what_is: Tuberkulos är en vanlig smittsam sjukdom orsakad av bakterier. Tuberkulos är fortfarande en stor orsak till sjukdom och död i stora delar av världen. Tuberkulos drabbar vanligtvis lungorna men kan också påverka andra organ. Symtom på lungtuberkulos är långvarig hosta och blod i slem. Feber, trötthet och viktminskning är också vanliga. Sjukdom kan utvecklas långt efter infektion. De flesta som är smittade utvecklar aldrig sjukdom.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination ingår inte längre i Danmarks nationella vaccinationsprogram för barn (upphörde på 1980-talet).

Vaccinet är ett levande försvagat vaccin. Vaccination kan övervägas särskilt för barn och ungdomar under långa vistelser i områden med hög förekomst. Prata med din läkare om huruvida du eller dina barn bör vaccineras.
occurrence: Varje år diagnostiseras omkring tio miljoner människor världen över med tuberkulos och nästan 1,8 miljoner av dem dör. Tuberkulos drabbar främst personer i arbetsför ålder men förekommer i alla åldersgrupper. Idag är tuberkulos mycket vanligare i fattiga länder, men sjukdomen förekommer fortfarande i alla europeiska länder.
source: Inandning av andningssekret.

typhoid.title: Tyfoidfeber
typhoid.description: Tyfoid är en allvarlig bakterieinfektion som sprids genom förorenad mat och vatten. Vaccination mot tyfoid ingår inte i de flesta länders nationella vaccinationsprogram.
what_is: Tyfoid orsakas av bakterien Salmonella Typhi och förekommer särskilt i områden med dålig hygien och begränsad tillgång till rent dricksvatten.
Symtom inkluderar långvarig feber, huvudvärk, buksmärta, trötthet, diarré eller förstoppning. Symtom uppträder vanligtvis 1–3 veckor efter infektion, men kan variera från person till person.
Sjukdomsförloppet kan variera från milda eller asymtomatiska fall, ofta hos barn, till allvarlig sjukdom hos vuxna. Obehandlad tyfoid kan vara livshotande.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination rekommenderas för resenärer till områden där tyfoid är vanligt.
Det finns två typer av vacciner: ett inaktiverat (injicerat) vaccin och ett levande försvagat (oralt) vaccin. Valet beror på ålder, hälsa och vistelsens längd.
Vaccination ger inte 100 % skydd, så det är fortfarande viktigt att följa strikt hygien för mat och vatten.
Boosterdoser kan behövas beroende på vaccin och exponering.
occurrence: Tyfoid förekommer globalt men är mest utbrett i Sydasien, Afrika och delar av Latinamerika.
Resenärer från områden med hög hygienstandard är särskilt utsatta, även vid vistelse på hotell med hög standard.
source: Smitta sker genom intag av mat eller vatten förorenat med avföring, eller genom direkt/indirekt kontakt med avföring.
Noggrann uppmärksamhet på mat- och vattensäkerhet vid resa är viktig, inklusive att undvika rå eller oskalad mat, obehandlade drycker och is från osäkra källor.

shingrix.title: Bältros
shingrix.description: Bältros är en smärtsam virussjukdom som orsakas av reaktivering av vattkoppsviruset. Vaccination finns för vuxna för att minska risken för sjukdom och långvarig nervsmärta.
what_is: Bältros uppstår när varicella-zosterviruset, som orsakar vattkoppor, reaktiveras senare i livet och orsakar ett smärtsamt utslag längs nerver.
Symtom inkluderar brännande eller stickande känsla, rodnad, vätskefyllda blåsor och ibland feber och trötthet. Smärtan kan vara i veckor eller månader även efter att utslagen har läkt.
Sjukdomens svårighetsgrad ökar med åldern och hos personer med nedsatt immunförsvar.
can_be_vaccinated: Shingrix rekommenderas för vuxna över 50 år.
Vaccinet ges i två doser med 2–6 månaders mellanrum.
Vaccination minskar avsevärt risken för bältros och postherpetisk neuralgi (långvarig nervsmärta).
Biverkningar är vanligtvis milda, såsom ömhet vid injektionsstället, trötthet eller mild feber.
occurrence: Bältros kan förekomma hos alla som tidigare haft vattkoppor.
Sjukdomen är vanligare hos äldre vuxna och personer med nedsatt immunförsvar.
source: Reaktivering av varicella-zosterviruset som redan finns i kroppen.
Viruset sprids inte genom normal kontakt, men kan orsaka vattkoppor hos personer som aldrig haft det.

prevenar20.title: Pneumokocksjukdom
prevenar20.description: Pneumokocksjukdom orsakas av Streptococcus pneumoniae och kan leda till lunginflammation, hjärnhinneinflammation och sepsis. Vaccination erbjuds till högriskgrupper.
what_is: Pneumokocksjukdom kan drabba alla åldersgrupper men är mest allvarlig hos små barn, äldre vuxna och personer med nedsatt immunförsvar.
Symtom beror på typ av infektion och kan inkludera feber, hosta, andningssvårigheter, huvudvärk eller stel nacke.
Sjukdomen kan utvecklas snabbt och kräva sjukhusvård i allvarliga fall.
can_be_vaccinated: Prevenar 20 skyddar mot 20 typer av pneumokockbakterier.
Vaccination rekommenderas för vuxna över 50 år och personer med ökad risk, t.ex. med kroniska sjukdomar.
Vaccinet används även för barn som en del av rutinmässiga vaccinationsprogram i många länder.
Boosterdoser kan behövas beroende på ålder och hälsotillstånd.
occurrence: Pneumokocksjukdom förekommer över hela världen, särskilt bland sårbara grupper.
Invasiv sjukdom är särskilt farlig för spädbarn, äldre vuxna och immunsupprimerade personer.
source: Bakterierna sprids via droppar från hosta eller nysning.
Nära kontakt med smittade personer ökar risken för smitta.

qdenga.title: Denguefeber
qdenga.description: Denguefeber är en virussjukdom som sprids av Aedes-mygor i tropiska och subtropiska områden. Vaccination kan minska risken för svår sjukdom.
what_is: Denguefeber orsakas av denguevirus och kan ge hög feber, svår huvudvärk, muskelsmärta, ledvärk, illamående och utslag.
I svåra fall kan dengue leda till blödningar, lågt blodtryck och chock, vilket kan vara livshotande.
Återhämtning kan ta flera veckor och trötthet kan kvarstå även efter att den akuta sjukdomen gått över.
can_be_vaccinated: Qdenga rekommenderas för personer som bor i eller reser till dengueendemiska områden.
Vaccinet ges i två doser med 3 månaders mellanrum till personer från 4 år och uppåt.
Vaccination kan minska risken för svår dengue och komplikationer.
Vaccination ersätter inte myggskydd såsom myggmedel, nät och skyddande kläder.
occurrence: Dengue är utbrett i Asien, Afrika, Latinamerika och Stillahavsregionen.
Resenärer från icke-endemiska områden är särskilt utsatta när de besöker endemiska länder.
source: Smitta sker genom bett från infekterade Aedes-mygor.
Myggkontroll, skyddande kläder och myggmedel är viktiga förebyggande åtgärder.

hepatitis_a.title: Hepatitis A
hepatitis_a.description: Hepatitis A, also called infectious hepatitis, is an acute infectious liver disease caused by a virus. Vaccination against hepatitis A is not part of the national vaccination program.
what_is: Hepatitis A, also called infectious hepatitis, is an acute infectious liver disease caused by a virus and transmitted fecal-orally. It is usually transmitted by consuming food or water contaminated with feces or through direct or indirect contact with feces. Hepatitis A is one of the most common serious infectious diseases that can be acquired during travel and can be prevented with vaccination.

Symptoms can last for several weeks or months. Hepatitis A virus does not cause chronic liver disease, but it can take several weeks to recover. Fatigue can continue for several months after the inflammation has subsided.

The clinical course varies from asymptomatic infection, which is common in young children, to symptomatic disease in adults or rarely life-threatening liver failure. The virus can also be transmitted by people with asymptomatic infection.
can_be_vaccinated: As a traveler, you must protect yourself against hepatitis A.

Authorities recommend vaccination against hepatitis A when traveling to areas with increased occurrence of hepatitis A. Additionally, intravenous drug users, household members under 18 years of age of hepatitis B infected persons, and people with hepatitis C should be recommended vaccination against both hepatitis A and B.
Families adopting children from areas where hepatitis A is endemic are recommended to be vaccinated before the child's arrival.

You can be vaccinated with a hepatitis A vaccine alone or with a vaccine that protects against both hepatitis A and hepatitis B. Both types can be given to adults and children over 1 year. Children under one year can receive immunoglobulin against hepatitis A instead (while hepatitis B vaccination can be given from birth).
After completing the vaccination series, long-lasting immunity against hepatitis A is generally achieved (and also against B if the combination vaccine was used).
hepatitis_a.protection: In addition to vaccination, you should avoid potential sources of infection by maintaining high hygiene standards and being aware of risks related to food and water consumption.
occurrence: Hepatitis A is widespread in large parts of the world and has increased occurrence in parts of Europe.
Tourists traveling from very high hygienic conditions to countries with poor hygiene are particularly at risk of getting the disease, regardless of hotel standards or similar.
source: Through consumption of water/drinks and food contaminated with feces, as well as other direct/indirect contact with feces.

It is therefore a good idea to follow general hygiene and food hygiene advice when traveling, such as hand hygiene and avoiding beverages (including ice cubes) that are not from sealed bottles, avoiding fruit you have not peeled yourself, and avoiding cold foods while choosing cooked or fried dishes that have just been prepared. Be aware that contamination of food can occur just before serving.

hepatitis_b.title: Hepatitis B
hepatitis_b.description: Hepatitis B is liver inflammation due to viral infection – potentially serious and chronic. Hepatitis B is widespread in large parts of the world.
what_is: Hepatitis B is a viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic liver inflammation.
The incubation period for hepatitis B is from one to six months. Whether symptoms occur depends among other things on the age at the time of infection.
The acute infection often occurs without symptoms, especially in young children. Most newborns infected at birth show no symptoms.
With symptomatic acute hepatitis B, one may experience flu-like symptoms such as headache, fever, fatigue, and body aches.
There may also be loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, itching, and joint pain.
The duration of illness varies from a few weeks to several months. Most adults recover and develop lifelong immunity.
In rare cases, acute hepatitis B can lead to life-threatening liver failure.
Chronic hepatitis B can develop after infection and can lead to cirrhosis and in rare cases liver cancer.
The risk of chronic infection is greatest in infants and young children. Up to 90% of children infected at birth develop chronic infection.
Many people live with chronic hepatitis B without ever having had symptoms of the acute infection.
can_be_vaccinated: The health authorities recommend vaccination against hepatitis B for certain risk groups.
This includes children of mothers with hepatitis B, household members and sexual partners of infected persons.
Other risk groups include certain professional groups, men who have sex with men, and persons with travel-related risk.
Vaccination can be given with hepatitis B vaccine alone or as a combination vaccine against both hepatitis A and B.
Hepatitis B vaccination can be given at all ages, including newborns.
hepatitis_b.protection: In addition to vaccination, you should avoid risky behavior such as unprotected sex and contact with blood, and ensure good hygiene during medical and cosmetic procedures.
occurrence: Hepatitis B is widespread in large parts of the world.
WHO estimated that around 257 million people globally lived with chronic hepatitis B in 2017.
The virus is found in blood and other bodily fluids and can survive outside the body for several days.
Even small amounts of blood can transmit the infection.
source: Unprotected sex.
Contact with blood, e.g., in accidents, medical or dental visits, blood transfusions, or contact sports.
Piercing and tattooing with non-sterile instruments.
Drug use via injection.
Contact between young children through bites, scratches, or wounds.
Transmission from mother to child during pregnancy or birth.
Normal household contact.

diphtheria.title: Diphtheria
diphtheria.description: Diphtheria is a bacterial infection. The toxin produced by the bacteria can damage nerves and heart muscle. Combination vaccinations that also protect against diphtheria are part of the national childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Diphtheria is a contagious disease that typically spreads through coughing and sneezing.
If an infected person has a skin infection, the disease can also spread through direct contact with wounds.
Symptoms of diphtheria include fever and sore throat.
In severe infection, thick gray-white coatings can be seen in the throat, as well as swollen and painful lymph nodes in the neck.
The diphtheria bacterium produces a toxin that can cause serious complications such as affecting the heart, muscles, kidneys, and nerves.
The disease can be fatal in severe cases.
Diphtheria can also occur as a skin infection with wound formation.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against diphtheria is part of the national childhood vaccination program.
Children are offered vaccination at 3, 5, and 12 months of age, with a booster at 5 years.
Subsequent revaccinations are not part of the childhood program.
The National Serum Institute recommends that adults be revaccinated against diphtheria and tetanus every 10 years.
Revaccination is also recommended for travel if the last vaccination was more than 10 years ago.
diphtheria.protection: Vaccination is the most important protection against diphtheria. Good hygiene and avoiding close contact with infected persons also reduce the risk of infection.
occurrence: Diphtheria is very rare in Denmark and most European countries.
However, the disease still occurs in some parts of the world, especially in areas with low vaccination coverage.
source: Infection via respiratory secretions, e.g., through coughing and sneezing.
Direct contact with wounds in case of skin infection.

tbe.title: TBE – Tick Borne Encephalitis
tbe.description: TBE is a viral disease transmitted by ticks and can cause serious brain inflammation.
what_is: TBE (Tick Borne Encephalitis) is a viral disease transmitted via tick bites in endemic areas.
Infection typically occurs within a few minutes after the tick bite through the tick’s saliva.
There is also a possible source of infection through consumption of unpasteurized milk.
Most infected persons remain symptom-free.
If symptoms occur, they often appear in two phases. The first phase usually occurs about a week after the tick bite and causes mild fever, headache, and significant fatigue.
This phase usually lasts a couple of days, and up to two-thirds of patients fully recover after this phase.
After 2–10 symptom-free days, about one in three patients develops the second phase with high fever and symptoms from the central nervous system.
It is estimated that around one in ten patients in the second phase develops long-term or permanent neurological symptoms.
TBE can be life-threatening, but the mortality is relatively low. The disease is most severe in older people, while children are less likely to experience severe courses.
can_be_vaccinated: TBE can be prevented with vaccination.
The vaccine does not protect against Lyme disease or other tick-borne diseases and does not prevent tick bites.
There is no vaccine against Lyme disease.
People who stay or travel to risk areas should consider vaccination depending on their exposure.
Talk to your doctor about whether vaccination is relevant.
Adults and children over 1 year can be vaccinated against TBE.
After completing the vaccination series, regular booster vaccinations are needed to maintain protection.
tbe.protection: In addition to vaccination, it is recommended to wear covering clothing and footwear in areas with ticks, especially in tall grass, shrubs, and forests. Rapid removal of ticks can reduce the risk of Lyme disease but does not prevent TBE, as the virus is transmitted within a few minutes after the bite.
occurrence: In Denmark, TBE occurs mainly on Bornholm.
A few cases have previously been registered in North Zealand.
TBE is also found in the Nordic countries, especially Sweden and Finland, as well as in several countries in Central Europe, the Baltic states, and Russia.
source: Infection via ticks found in nature.

mumps.title: Mumps
mumps.description: Mumps is a viral disease with symptoms including fever, headache, lack of appetite, and painful swelling of the salivary glands under the ears, on one or both sides.
what_is: Mumps is a contagious viral disease.
Typical symptoms include fever, headache, lack of appetite, and swelling of the salivary glands under the ears, causing swelling in the jaw area.
The swelling can occur on one or both sides.
Mumps can sometimes lead to complications such as testicular inflammation, meningitis, and in rare cases deafness.
Serious complications are rare today due to high vaccination coverage.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against mumps is part of the national childhood vaccination program.
The vaccine is included in the MMR vaccine, which also protects against measles and rubella.
Two doses of MMR vaccine are given at 15 months and again at 4 years.
mumps.protection: Vaccination is the most important protection against mumps. Good hygiene and avoiding close contact with infected persons can reduce the risk of infection.
occurrence: Mumps occurs rarely in Denmark due to high vaccination coverage.
Outbreaks can occur among unvaccinated or partially vaccinated people.
source: Transmission via respiratory secretions or saliva.

yellow_fever.title: Yellow fever
yellow_fever.description: Yellow fever is an acute viral disease transmitted by mosquito bites and can lead to hemorrhagic fever and death. Vaccination is not part of the national vaccination program.
what_is: Yellow fever is an acute viral disease transmitted by mosquito bites and can lead to hemorrhagic fever. Early symptoms are fever and nausea. In the second, more severe 'yellow' phase, the disease can cause bleeding, kidney or liver failure, and death.
can_be_vaccinated: As a rule of thumb, vaccination against yellow fever is recommended for everyone over 9 months traveling to an area where yellow fever occurs – especially if the destination is a rural area, jungle, or savannah (see recommendations for each country and talk to your doctor).
It is the traveler’s responsibility to ensure correct vaccination, as it is not part of the national vaccination program.

The vaccination is given in a single dose and provides lifelong immunity. The vaccine should be taken 10 days before arrival in the risk area. According to WHO, the vaccination becomes effective 10 days after vaccination, and if valid, it is valid for life.

Some countries require proof of vaccination from travelers arriving from countries considered risk areas for yellow fever. According to WHO’s statement from July 2016, proof of vaccination is valid for life. In certain countries, mainly in West Africa, there is also a requirement that all travelers can present proof of vaccination. These conditions can change continuously, so travelers are advised to consult their doctor, vaccination clinic, and possibly the embassy.

According to SSI, travelers with reduced immune function should not be vaccinated against yellow fever, as the vaccine contains live, weakened yellow fever virus. Pregnant women, breastfeeding women, and children under 9 months should not be vaccinated unless special circumstances apply.
If you are pregnant and not previously vaccinated, you should consult your doctor and consider postponing travel until after pregnancy.

If the vaccination is not given for medical reasons, an exemption letter or written justification for lack of vaccination must be attached to the international vaccination documentation. The letter or justification must be in English and signed by a doctor.
yellow_fever.protection: In endemic areas, the risk of infection can be reduced by using insect repellent, clothing, and mosquito nets treated with permethrin.
occurrence: Yellow fever occurs in tropical areas, especially in rural areas, jungle, and savannah in Africa and Central and South America. Urban outbreaks occur.
source: The disease is transmitted by mosquitoes.

haemophilus.title: Diseases caused by Haemophilus bacteria
haemophilus.description: Several serious diseases such as meningitis, epiglottitis, and pneumonia can be caused by Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib).
what_is: Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is a bacterium that can cause a range of infections.
The infections range from mild illnesses like ear infections to severe and life-threatening diseases.
Serious diseases include meningitis, epiglottitis, and pneumonia.
The diseases mainly affect children under 5 years.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is part of the national childhood vaccination program.
The vaccine is given as part of the infant program.
Vaccination is given at 3, 5, and 12 months of age.
haemophilus.protection: Vaccination provides effective protection against serious Hib infections. Good hygiene and avoiding infection can further reduce the risk.
occurrence: Before the Hib vaccine was introduced in Denmark, the bacterium was a common cause of serious meningitis and deaths among small children.
After vaccination was introduced, the disease has almost been eradicated in Denmark.
The Hib vaccine does not protect against meningitis caused by viruses or other bacteria than Hib.
source: Transmission via inhalation of respiratory secretions.

hpv.title: HPV Infection (Human Papillomavirus)
hpv.description: Infection with HPV (human papillomavirus) is the main cause of cervical cancer. Vaccination is part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
what_is: HPV (human papillomavirus) includes around 100 different virus types.
Less than 20 of these are considered high-risk types because of their association with cervical cancer and other cancers, including cancer at the anus.
HPV types 16 and 18 are responsible for about 70% of all cervical cancer cases.
HPV is mainly transmitted through sexual contact or contact with an infected person’s genitals.
Using condoms reduces the risk of infection but does not provide full protection.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against HPV is part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
The vaccine is offered to girls and boys at age 12.
Vaccination is given in two doses.
The vaccine protects against the most common cancer-causing HPV types.
Vaccination prevents cell changes in the cervix that can develop into cancer.
Some HPV vaccines also protect against HPV types that cause genital warts.
hpv.protection: Even after vaccination, regular cervical screening is important as part of the national screening program, as the vaccine does not protect against all cancer-causing HPV types. Safe sex is always recommended, but condoms do not provide full protection against HPV since the virus can also be transmitted through skin contact around the genitals.
occurrence: HPV is very common and spreads easily.
Most sexually active people become infected with HPV at least once in their lifetime.
Most infections clear on their own, but certain high-risk types can lead to cancer over time.
source: Transmission through sexual contact.

influenza.title: Influenza
influenza.description: Influenza is a febrile and potentially serious contagious respiratory disease transmitted via respiratory secretions. Danish health authorities recommend vaccination against seasonal influenza for certain risk groups.
what_is: Influenza is an acute viral infection that can easily spread from person to person.
In temperate climates, influenza is typically a winter disease that returns annually as seasonal influenza.
Influenza viruses occur worldwide and can affect people of all ages.
Typical symptoms include fever, muscle aches, cough, and other respiratory symptoms.
Influenza can be serious and in some cases life-threatening, especially for people in risk groups such as pregnant women, people over 65, and people with chronic diseases.
Contagiousness often starts shortly before symptom onset, and most recover within two weeks.
Common complications include pneumonia and worsening of existing chronic diseases, and in rare cases the disease can cause death.
influenza.when: Seasonal influenza typically occurs between October and February.
can_be_vaccinated: Danish health authorities recommend vaccination against seasonal influenza for risk groups.
Risk groups include pregnant women after 12 weeks, people over 65, people with chronic diseases, and severely overweight individuals.
Talk to your doctor about whether flu vaccination is relevant for you.
Others, including travelers, may choose vaccination at their own expense.
The flu vaccine changes every year and only provides protection for one season.
The vaccine protects against influenza A and B viruses but not against other respiratory infections with flu-like symptoms.
influenza.protection: Vaccination is the most important prevention against influenza. In addition, good hand hygiene and avoiding close contact with infected people are recommended to reduce the risk of infection.
occurrence: Every few years, actual influenza epidemics occur, where up to 20% of the population can become ill.
In temperate climates, influenza activity peaks in winter months.
In tropical and subtropical areas, influenza can occur year-round, often with higher activity during rainy seasons or cool periods.
Rarely, new influenza viruses can cause pandemics, which can occur outside the normal influenza season.
source: Transmission via respiratory secretions that spread through inhalation or direct contact.

japanese_brain_inflammation.title: Japanese encephalitis
japanese_brain_inflammation.description: Japanese encephalitis is a serious viral infection transmitted by mosquito bites and can be fatal. Vaccination is not part of the national vaccination program.
what_is: Japanese encephalitis is a serious viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes.
Most infected persons have no or only mild symptoms such as fever and headache.
In some cases, severe disease develops with meningitis, encephalitis, and other complications.
Although only a small proportion of infections lead to illness, mortality among sick patients is high and can be up to 30%.
The disease can cause lasting neurological damage in survivors.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against Japanese encephalitis is not part of the national vaccination program.
Travelers to risk areas should ensure adequate protection themselves.
Talk to your doctor or a vaccination clinic about the need for vaccination when traveling.
There are several different vaccines against Japanese encephalitis with varying vaccination schedules.
japanese_brain_inflammation.protection: In endemic areas, the risk of infection can be reduced by using mosquito repellent, mosquito nets, and covering clothing, preferably treated with insecticide. Children should be especially protected from mosquito bites.
occurrence: Japanese encephalitis occurs in large parts of Asia.
Occurrence is often highest during the rainy season.
The spread varies significantly from region to region and from year to year.
source: Transmission via mosquitoes.

whooping_cough.title: Whooping Cough
whooping_cough.description: Whooping cough is a highly contagious bacterial disease with symptoms such as respiratory infection and severe coughing fits. Vaccination is part of the national childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Whooping cough is a bacterial disease that affects the respiratory tract.
The bacteria spread through respiratory mucous membranes and produce toxins that attack the mucous membranes and the body’s defense mechanisms.
The incubation period is up to two weeks.
The disease often starts with mild cough, runny nose, slight fever, and sore throat and later develops into severe coughing fits with uncontrollable coughing.
In children, the coughing fits are often severe and may be followed by vomiting and characteristic high-pitched (whooping) breathing.
In infants, whooping cough can be life-threatening and lead to insufficient breathing and lack of oxygen, which can cause bluish discoloration of the skin.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against whooping cough is part of the national childhood vaccination program and is given at 3, 5, and 12 months of age.
A booster vaccination is given at 5 years as part of the diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough, and polio booster.
Vaccination and natural infection do not provide lasting immunity.
whooping_cough.protection: Antibiotic treatment should be started early to have some effect. With pronounced symptoms, antibiotics rarely affect the course of the disease but can reduce the risk of infection to others.
source: Transmission via respiratory secretions through close contact between people.

cholera.title: Cholera
cholera.description: Cholera is a bacterial disease that can cause severe diarrhea. The disease spreads easily through contaminated water and food. Vaccination is not part of the national vaccination program.
what_is: Cholera is a serious bacterial disease that causes severe watery diarrhea.
The disease can be life-threatening due to rapid and extensive loss of fluids and salts (dehydration).
Cholera is primarily transmitted through water and food contaminated with feces.
Person-to-person transmission occurs only rarely.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against cholera is not part of the national vaccination program.
Travelers are responsible for assessing the need for vaccination.
Vaccination can be considered when staying in risk areas under special conditions.
Talk to your doctor or a vaccination clinic about whether vaccination is relevant.
cholera.protection: When traveling to areas with cholera, good hygiene should be followed, including thorough handwashing before meals and after toilet use. Avoid undercooked food, especially shellfish. Drink only bottled water and avoid ice cubes and possibly contaminated tap water.
occurrence: Cholera spreads easily in areas with poor access to clean water and sanitation.
Worldwide, it is estimated that there are 1.3 to 4.0 million cases of cholera annually.
Each year between 21,000 and 143,000 deaths are reported due to the disease.
Cholera occurs mainly in Africa and parts of Asia, including India and Indonesia.
Outbreaks in South and Central America are rare.
source: Contaminated drinking water
Contaminated food, especially if served raw or cold
Poor sanitation and toilet facilities

malaria.title: Malaria
malaria.description: A serious, potentially life-threatening fever disease caused by malaria parasites and spread by mosquitoes. Preventive treatment with malaria medicine can be used.
what_is: Malaria is a serious, potentially life-threatening fever disease caused by malaria parasites and spread by mosquitoes. Just one bite from an infected mosquito can cause infection.
Typical symptoms include flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, sweating, headache, abdominal pain, and nausea.
Malaria can cause serious complications, and untreated it can be fatal, especially falciparum malaria.
Most deaths occur in children and pregnant women in endemic areas.
Malaria requires urgent treatment.
can_be_vaccinated: There is no widely available malaria vaccine in Denmark yet, but the disease can be prevented with malaria medicine and mosquito protection.
Preventive malaria medicine is prescribed individually for each trip by a doctor.
The medicine is prescription-only and is purchased and paid for by the patient at the pharmacy.
You should not travel to malaria-affected areas without proper protection.
protection: Preventive malaria medicine must be taken according to the doctor’s instructions, and the last doses are taken after the trip.
There are different types of malaria medicine, and the doctor chooses the most suitable based on individual assessment.
In endemic areas, the risk can be reduced with mosquito protection, especially at night: insect repellents, clothing, and mosquito nets treated with permethrin.
No prevention gives 100% protection, and you can get malaria even if you have taken medicine.
If you become ill after traveling in malaria areas, you should always inform the doctor.
occurrence: The risk of malaria is highest in tropical parts of Africa and parts of the Pacific region.
The risk is moderate in southern Asia.
In Central and South America and Southeast Asia, the risk is generally lower.
In recent years, between 80–100 cases of malaria are seen in Denmark each year, mostly infected in Africa, and most with the most severe form.
source: Anopheles mosquitoes, which are especially active at dusk, at night, and in the morning.

meningococcal_diseases.title: Meningococcal Diseases
meningococcal_diseases.description: Meningococcal diseases can occur in people of all ages, but outbreaks are mainly seen among children and young people.
what_is: Meningococci are bacteria that can cause meningitis and/or blood poisoning, which can develop rapidly and be fatal.
Symptoms include fever, stiff neck, altered consciousness, and rapid deterioration of general health.
The most relevant meningococcal groups associated with severe disease are A, B, C, W, and Y.
can_be_vaccinated: In Denmark, vaccines are available against group B, group C, and combined vaccines against group ACWY.
Talk to your doctor about your vaccination needs and the need for booster/revaccination.
In the USA and some other countries, vaccination may be required for foreign exchange students.
Vaccination is especially recommended for travelers planning to stay in areas with high occurrence in Africa south of the Sahara (the meningitis belt).
Saudi Arabia requires pilgrims to document quadrivalent vaccination against meningococcal diseases (A, C, W135, and Y).
Vaccination is not part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
occurrence: Meningococcal diseases can occur in people of all ages but are most common among young children and young adults.
Outbreaks of the disease can especially occur among young adults.
source: The disease is transmitted via respiratory secretions from person to person.
Transmission occurs through close contact, e.g., living with or kissing an infected person.

measles.title: Measles
measles.description: A contagious viral infection that starts with respiratory infection symptoms and causes rash all over the body. The disease can be severe. MMR vaccination (measles, mumps, and rubella) is part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Measles is an infection caused by a virus. Early symptoms include fever, runny nose, and red eyes. As the disease progresses, a rash develops, starting on the face and then spreading all over the body. This can last up to seven days.
Measles is one of the most contagious diseases known, and the risk of non-immune persons becoming infected through contact with an infected person is very high.
The most common complications associated with measles are pneumonia and ear infection. In more rare cases, encephalitis can occur. Measles can be life-threatening.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against measles is part of the childhood vaccination program. The MMR vaccine, which includes measles vaccination, also immunizes against rubella and mumps.
Vaccinations are given at 15 months and again at 4 years (moved forward from 12 years previously).
SSI recommends that people who are not immune to measles (either vaccinated as a child or have had the disease) be vaccinated, especially before traveling to areas with measles circulation.
Vaccination is also recommended for adults who are not immune, especially healthcare personnel and travelers to high-risk areas.
occurrence: With vaccination, the number of measles cases has decreased worldwide, but the disease is still widespread globally and still occurs sporadically in Denmark due to insufficient vaccination coverage.
Measles are still present in several EU countries, and in 2017, more than 21,000 cases and 35 deaths were reported in the WHO European region.
source: Respiratory secretions in the form of small droplets that can spread through the air.
Infection can occur through close contact, e.g., being in the same room as an infected person, as the virus can spread through coughing and sneezing.

pneumococcal_diseases.title: Pneumococcal Diseases
pneumococcal_diseases.description: Pneumococci are bacteria that can cause serious diseases such as meningitis and blood poisoning. Vaccination against several pneumococcal types is part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Serious pneumococcal diseases are mainly seen in young children and older adults and people with weakened immune systems. In addition to severe cases of meningitis and blood poisoning, pneumococci are also a common cause of pneumonia, sinusitis, and ear infections in children. The bacterium is divided into different serotypes that vary in occurrence.
can_be_vaccinated: There are several types of vaccines against pneumococcal disease that protect against a number of the most common pneumococcal types.
Vaccination is part of the Danish childhood vaccination program and is given as 3 doses at 3, 5, and 12 months of age.
In addition, health authorities recommend vaccination for a number of people with increased risk of serious pneumococcal disease.
occurrence: It is common to carry pneumococci in the nasopharynx without becoming ill. Carrier status is particularly common among children.
source: Transmitted via respiratory secretions.

polio.title: Polio
polio.description: Polio is an extremely contagious viral disease that can cause meningitis and paralysis and can be life-threatening. Vaccination is part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Polio (poliomyelitis) is a contagious viral disease. Over 90% of all cases are without symptoms.

Early symptoms resemble those of common influenza, such as fever, sore throat, and malaise. For most, the illness ends here, but in 1–5% of cases, the virus attacks the nervous system as meningitis with more severe symptoms and can be life-threatening if it paralyzes the breathing muscles.
Less than 1% of all polio infections cause paralysis. Many years after the acute phase, patients who have had paralysis can still experience significant long-term effects.
can_be_vaccinated: Polio vaccination is part of the national vaccination program.
Vaccination is offered as part of the childhood program at 3, 5, and 12 months, with a booster/revaccination when the child is 5 years old.

There are a few countries where polio virus still occurs. There may be requirements for polio revaccination for travel to these countries. Talk to your doctor or vaccination clinic about the latest recommendations regarding polio in connection with your travel.
occurrence: There is hope of eradicating polio completely, but poliovirus still circulates in a few countries.
source: The virus is mainly transmitted from person to person or via infected food or drink. Polio is extremely contagious, but in most cases without symptoms.

rabies.title: Rabies
rabies.description: A viral disease affecting the central nervous system and eventually causing encephalitis and death. Rabies is transmitted via saliva from an infected animal. Vaccination is not part of the national childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Rabies is a viral disease affecting the central nervous system and eventually causing encephalitis and death. The disease is transmitted to humans via saliva from an infected animal, typically through a bite or when saliva comes into contact with open wounds or mucous membranes by the animal licking them.
Symptoms appear typically a few weeks to several months after a bite. Early symptoms include fever, headache, and malaise, followed by symptoms of encephalitis, e.g., hallucinations.
Infected persons can also react to water and have seizures with breathing and swallowing difficulties, described as hydrophobia. Paralysis may also occur.
Once symptoms appear, rabies cannot be cured and will result in death, but the disease can be prevented with vaccination (possibly combined with immunoglobulin).
can_be_vaccinated: You must arrange vaccination against rabies yourself, as it is not part of the national vaccination program.

The need for vaccination before exposure is assessed individually. It is extremely important that you still seek medical attention immediately after exposure to receive additional vaccines to prevent the disease, even if you have been vaccinated previously.

If you are bitten or exposed to saliva, for example by an animal that may be infected with rabies, it is important to thoroughly wash the wound and seek medical attention immediately – even if you have been vaccinated previously, as you need additional vaccinations to prevent the disease.

There is also preventive treatment that can be started after exposure, even without prior vaccination. It must be started immediately after the bite to counteract the deadly disease and consists of both vaccinations and rabies immunoglobulin injections.

Since rabies virus can be present in a person’s tissue long before symptoms start, it is important that travelers bitten by an animal that may be infected with rabies complete the preventive treatment, even if a long time has passed since the bite.
Talk to your doctor about the risk of rabies during your travel and whether you should be vaccinated before the trip and how to act in case of exposure.
occurrence: Rabies occurs worldwide, and it is estimated that over 55,000 people, mainly in Africa and Asia, die from the disease each year. In Denmark, rabies occurs in bats.
source: Bite or lick from an infected animal, where saliva enters the wound or mucous membranes.

rotavirus.title: Rotavirus
rotavirus.description: A virus that causes diarrhea that can be serious in infants and young children, especially between 6 and 18 months of age. Vaccination is not part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Rotavirus causes disease with diarrhea and vomiting, especially in children aged 6 to 18 months. Among adults, the disease is less common and much milder and shorter. The disease is associated with the risk of dehydration, especially in infants, which can be serious (life-threatening) and require hospitalization for intravenous fluid treatment.

Symptoms of rotavirus infection include watery diarrhea, vomiting, and sometimes fever, which together can quickly lead to fluid loss. Symptoms usually last about five days but can last significantly longer in infants.
The incubation period is a couple of days, and large amounts of the virus are shed in the feces for about a week.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination is not part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
Vaccines against rotavirus are available. Depending on the product, the vaccine is taken orally in two or three doses.
occurrence: Rotavirus is a very common cause of disease with diarrhea and vomiting in children both in Denmark and worldwide. Rotavirus is highly contagious and almost all children have been infected by the age of 2–3 years.
The disease is seasonal – in Denmark typically December to April.
In Denmark, rotavirus-related deaths are extremely rare, but according to WHO calculations, there were about 453,000 deaths among children in 2008 due to rotavirus-related gastroenteritis.
source: Direct or indirect ingestion of feces from infected persons.
Physical contact with other people
Infection via touching toys and door handles
Ingestion of contaminated food or drink.

rubella.title: Rubella
rubella.description: A contagious viral disease that is usually mild but can be serious for pregnant women due to a high risk of birth defects if infected early in pregnancy. MMR vaccination is part of the national childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Rubella is a contagious disease caused by a virus. Common symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fever, headache, reddish rash, and joint pain, but the disease can also be asymptomatic.
In pregnant women, rubella can cause miscarriage or serious birth defects, especially early in pregnancy.
can_be_vaccinated: The rubella vaccine is part of the national childhood vaccination program. The MMR vaccine, which includes rubella vaccination, also immunizes against measles and mumps. Vaccinations are given at 15 months and 4 years (moved forward from 12 years previously).

Adult women who are not vaccinated (or have not had the disease) are recommended to be vaccinated due to the risk of serious birth defects in pregnancy and are offered free vaccination. The vaccine must not be given to pregnant women.
occurrence: Rubella is almost eradicated in Denmark due to vaccination. The disease still occurs in many places worldwide – outbreaks also occur in Europe.
source: Airborne via inhalation of respiratory secretions (droplets) from an infected person.
Talk to your doctor about vaccination

chickenpox.title: Chickenpox
chickenpox.description: A disease caused by a virus. In Denmark, most people get infected as children. The virus can later cause shingles in people who have had chickenpox. Vaccination is not part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Chickenpox is a very common childhood disease caused by the Varicella Zoster virus. The risk of complications is higher in adults and people with weakened immune systems than in healthy children. During pregnancy, the disease can cause complications for the mother and is serious for the newborn if the mother is infected around the time of birth. There is also a small risk of birth defects. For people with weakened immune systems, chickenpox can be severe and even life-threatening.
Chickenpox can cause complications such as pneumonia, encephalitis, and bacterial skin infection.

Symptoms of chickenpox appear 10–20 days after infection. During this period, the virus first multiplies in the respiratory tract and then spreads to the rest of the body, causing a rash. Before the rash appears, you may have mild fever and symptoms of a common cold. The rash first appears as red spots, which then enlarge and develop into blisters. The blister phase is followed by a phase with dry skin and scabs while the blisters heal if no bacterial infection develops. Fever may also occur, especially if there are many blisters.

The virus is easily transmitted through the air and small droplets of blister fluid. After recovery, the virus remains inactive in nerve cells and can reactivate later in life to cause shingles. The blisters associated with shingles also contain infectious virus and can thus infect non-immune people with chickenpox.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination is not part of the Danish childhood vaccination program.

Vaccines against chickenpox are available in Denmark, typically for people with special risk factors – including women of childbearing age who have not had chickenpox (but the vaccine must not be given to pregnant women, and pregnancy should be avoided for a period after vaccination).
Talk to your doctor about whether you should be vaccinated.
You can try to avoid infection by avoiding contact with patients with symptoms. For certain risk groups, the doctor may decide to give immunoglobulin after exposure.
occurrence: It is estimated that 98% of adult Danes raised in Denmark have had chickenpox. The disease is less common in tropical areas, where a larger proportion of adults have not had it.
source: Transmission is airborne from person to person via respiratory secretions and small droplets of blister fluid
Direct contact with fluid from blisters on the skin

tetanus.title: Tetanus
tetanus.description: A disease caused by infection with a bacterium commonly found in soil. Combination vaccination that also covers tetanus is part of the national childhood vaccination program.
what_is: Tetanus is a bacterial disease with symptoms including headache, muscle stiffness, and severe muscle spasms. The bacterium is normally found in soil. It enters through a wound or scratch in the skin and begins producing toxins, causing muscle contractions and a spasm condition that can be life-threatening.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination against tetanus is part of the national childhood vaccination program.

Tetanus vaccination is given in three doses at 3, 5, and 12 months of age. A single booster dose is given when the child turns 5 years old. Subsequent booster vaccination is not part of the program as such.
SSI recommends that everyone be revaccinated against diphtheria and tetanus every 10 years.
Revaccination is also recommended for travel abroad if the last vaccination was more than 10 years ago.

Vaccination provides the most important protection. To avoid infection, ensure that open wounds, scratches, and abrasions are properly protected from contact with soil, sand, and other potential sources of infection.
occurrence: Vaccinations, improved hygiene, and medication have greatly reduced the number of tetanus cases in the West. In Denmark, the disease does not occur in infants, but in developing countries it is still a common cause of death among small children. WHO estimated that 50,000 infants died of tetanus in 2008.
source: Infected soil in open wounds.

tuberculosis.title: Tuberculosis
tuberculosis.description: A contagious and potentially deadly bacterial disease that is widespread worldwide.
what_is: Tuberculosis is a common contagious disease caused by bacteria. Tuberculosis remains a major cause of illness and death in large parts of the world. Tuberculosis usually affects the lungs but can also affect other organs. Symptoms of pulmonary tuberculosis are prolonged cough and blood in sputum. Fever, fatigue, and weight loss are also common. Disease can develop long after infection. Most infected people never develop disease.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination is no longer part of the Danish childhood vaccination program (ceased in the 1980s).

The vaccine is a live weakened vaccine. Vaccination may be considered especially for children and young people during long stays in areas with high occurrence. Talk to your doctor about whether you or your children should be vaccinated.
occurrence: Each year about ten million people worldwide are diagnosed with tuberculosis, and almost 1.8 million of them die. Tuberculosis mainly affects people of working age but occurs in all age groups. Today, tuberculosis is much more common in poor countries, but the disease still occurs in all European countries.
source: Inhalation of respiratory secretions.

typhoid.title: Typhoid Fever
typhoid.description: Typhoid is a serious bacterial infection that spreads through contaminated food and water. Vaccination against typhoid is not included in most countries’ national vaccination programs.
what_is: Typhoid is caused by the bacterium Salmonella Typhi and occurs especially in areas with poor hygiene and limited access to clean drinking water.
Symptoms include prolonged fever, headache, abdominal pain, fatigue, diarrhea or constipation. Symptoms typically appear 1–3 weeks after infection, but can vary from person to person.
The course of illness can vary from mild or asymptomatic cases, often in children, to severe disease in adults. Untreated typhoid can be life-threatening.
can_be_vaccinated: Vaccination is recommended for travelers to areas where typhoid is common.
There are two types of vaccines: an inactivated (injection) vaccine and a live attenuated (oral) vaccine. The choice depends on age, health, and length of stay.
Vaccination does not provide 100% protection, so it is still important to follow strict hygiene measures for food and water.
Booster doses may be necessary depending on the vaccine and exposure risk.
occurrence: Typhoid occurs globally, but is most widespread in South Asia, Africa, and parts of Latin America.
Travelers from areas with high hygiene standards are especially at risk, even when staying at high-standard hotels.
source: Transmission occurs through ingestion of food or water contaminated with feces, or through direct/indirect contact with feces.
Strict attention to food and water hygiene during travel is important, including avoiding raw or unpeeled foods, untreated drinks, and ice from unsafe sources.

shingrix.title: Shingles
shingrix.description: Shingles is a painful viral disease caused by reactivation of the chickenpox virus. Vaccination is available for adults to reduce the risk of illness and long-term nerve pain.
what_is: Shingles occurs when the varicella-zoster virus, which causes chickenpox, reactivates later in life and causes a painful rash along nerves.
Symptoms include burning or tingling, redness, fluid-filled blisters, and sometimes fever and fatigue. Pain can last for weeks or months even after the rash has healed.
The severity of illness increases with age and in people with weakened immune systems.
can_be_vaccinated: Shingrix is recommended for adults over 50 years old.
The vaccine is given as two doses 2–6 months apart.
Vaccination significantly reduces the risk of shingles and postherpetic neuralgia (long-term nerve pain).
Side effects are usually mild, such as soreness at the injection site, fatigue, or mild fever.
occurrence: Shingles can occur in anyone who has previously had chickenpox.
The disease is more common in older adults and people with weakened immune systems.
source: Reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus that already exists in the body.
The virus does not spread through normal contact, but can cause chickenpox in people who have never had it.

prevenar20.title: Pneumococcal Disease
prevenar20.description: Pneumococcal disease is caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae and can lead to pneumonia, meningitis, and sepsis. Vaccination is offered to high-risk groups.
what_is: Pneumococcal disease can affect all age groups, but is most severe in young children, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems.
Symptoms depend on the type of infection and may include fever, cough, breathing difficulties, headache, or stiff neck.
The disease can progress quickly and require hospitalization in severe cases.
can_be_vaccinated: Prevenar 20 protects against 20 types of pneumococcal bacteria.
Vaccination is recommended for adults over 50 and people at increased risk, e.g., with chronic diseases.
The vaccine is also used for children as part of routine vaccination programs in many countries.
Booster doses may be necessary depending on age and health status.
occurrence: Pneumococcal disease occurs worldwide, especially among vulnerable groups.
Invasive disease is particularly dangerous for infants, older adults, and immunocompromised people.
source: The bacteria spread via droplets from coughing or sneezing.
Close contact with infected people increases the risk of transmission.

qdenga.title: Dengue Fever
qdenga.description: Dengue fever is a viral disease transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes in tropical and subtropical areas. Vaccination can reduce the risk of severe disease.
what_is: Dengue fever is caused by the dengue virus and can cause high fever, severe headache, muscle pain, joint pain, nausea, and rash.
In severe cases, dengue can lead to bleeding, low blood pressure, and shock, which can be life-threatening.
Recovery can take several weeks, and fatigue may continue even after the acute illness has passed.
can_be_vaccinated: Qdenga is recommended for people who live in or travel to dengue-endemic areas.
The vaccine is given as two doses 3 months apart to people aged 4 years and older.
Vaccination can reduce the risk of severe dengue and complications.
Vaccination does not replace mosquito protection such as repellent, nets, and protective clothing.
occurrence: Dengue is widespread in Asia, Africa, Latin America, and the Pacific.
Travelers from non-endemic areas are especially at risk when visiting endemic countries.
source: Transmission occurs through bites from infected Aedes mosquitoes.
Mosquito control, protective clothing, and repellents are important preventive measures.

welcome.title: Добро пожаловать на нашу страницу вакцинации

hepatitis_a.title: Гепатит А
hepatitis_a.description: Гепатит А, также называемый инфекционным гепатитом, — это острое инфекционное заболевание печени, вызываемое вирусом. Вакцинация против гепатита А не входит в национальную программу вакцинации.
what_is: Гепатит А, также называемый инфекционным гепатитом, — это острое инфекционное заболевание печени, вызываемое вирусом и передающееся фекально-оральным путем. Обычно передается через употребление пищи или воды, загрязненных фекалиями, либо через прямой или косвенный контакт с фекалиями. Гепатит А — одно из самых распространённых серьёзных инфекционных заболеваний, которое можно получить во время путешествий, и его можно предотвратить вакцинацией.

Симптомы могут длиться несколько недель или месяцев. Вирус гепатита А не вызывает хроническое заболевание печени, но восстановление может занять несколько недель. Усталость может сохраняться несколько месяцев после того, как воспаление прошло.

Клиническое течение варьируется от бессимптомной инфекции (что часто бывает у маленьких детей) до симптоматического заболевания у взрослых или, в редких случаях, угрожающей жизни печёночной недостаточности. Вирус также может передаваться людьми с бессимптомной инфекцией.
can_be_vaccinated: Как путешественник, вы должны защитить себя от гепатита А.

Власти рекомендуют вакцинацию против гепатита А при поездках в регионы с повышенной распространённостью гепатита А. Кроме того, людям, употребляющим инъекционные наркотики, членам семьи до 18 лет людей с гепатитом B и людям с гепатитом C рекомендуется вакцинация как против гепатита А, так и В.
Семьям, усыновляющим детей из районов, где гепатит А эндемичен, рекомендуется пройти вакцинацию до приезда ребёнка.

Вы можете быть вакцинированы вакциной только против гепатита А или комбинированной вакциной против гепатита А и В. Оба типа можно вводить взрослым и детям старше 1 года. Дети до одного года могут получить иммуноглобулин против гепатита А (в то время как вакцинация против гепатита В возможна с рождения).
После завершения серии вакцинации обычно достигается длительный иммунитет против гепатита А (а также против B, если использовалась комбинированная вакцина).
hepatitis_a.protection: Помимо вакцинации, следует избегать потенциальных источников инфекции, соблюдая высокие стандарты гигиены и учитывая риски, связанные с употреблением пищи и воды.
occurrence: Гепатит А широко распространён в больших частях мира и имеет повышенную распространённость в некоторых регионах Европы.
Туристы, путешествующие из зон с очень высоким уровнем гигиены в страны с плохими санитарными условиями, особенно подвержены риску заболевания, независимо от уровня гостиницы или подобного.
source: Через употребление воды/напитков и пищи, загрязнённых фекалиями, а также через другой прямой/косвенный контакт с фекалиями.

Поэтому при путешествиях полезно соблюдать общие гигиенические и пищевые рекомендации, такие как гигиена рук, избегание напитков (включая кубики льда), не из запечатанных бутылок, избегание фруктов, которые вы не очистили сами, и избегание холодных блюд, выбирая приготовленные или жареные блюда. Учтите, что заражение пищи может произойти непосредственно перед подачей.

hepatitis_b.title: Гепатит Б
hepatitis_b.description: Гепатит B — воспаление печени, вызванное вирусной инфекцией, которое может быть серьёзным и хроническим. Гепатит B широко распространён в больших частях мира.
what_is: Гепатит B — вирусная инфекция, которая поражает печень и может вызвать как острое, так и хроническое воспаление печени.
Инкубационный период гепатита B составляет от одного до шести месяцев. Наличие симптомов зависит, среди прочего, от возраста в момент заражения.
Острая инфекция часто протекает бессимптомно, особенно у маленьких детей. Большинство новорождённых, инфицированных при рождении, не имеют симптомов.
При симптоматическом остром гепатите B могут возникать симптомы, похожие на грипп, такие как головная боль, температура, усталость и боли в теле.
Могут также наблюдаться потеря аппетита, тошнота, рвота, боли в животе, желтуха, тёмная моча, светлый стул, зуд и боли в суставах.
Продолжительность заболевания варьируется от нескольких недель до нескольких месяцев. Большинство взрослых выздоравливают и вырабатывают пожизненный иммунитет.
В редких случаях острый гепатит B может привести к опасной для жизни печёночной недостаточности.
После заражения может развиться хронический гепатит B, который может привести к циррозу и в редких случаях к раку печени.
Риск хронической инфекции наиболее высок у младенцев и маленьких детей. До 90% детей, инфицированных при рождении, развивают хроническую инфекцию.
Многие люди живут с хроническим гепатитом B, не имея симптомов острой инфекции.
can_be_vaccinated: Власти здравоохранения рекомендуют вакцинацию против гепатита B для некоторых групп риска.
Это включает детей матерей с гепатитом B, членов семьи и сексуальных партнёров инфицированных людей.
Другие группы риска включают некоторые профессиональные группы, мужчин, имеющих секс с мужчинами, и людей с риском, связанным с путешествиями.
Вакцинация может проводиться как вакциной только против гепатита B, так и комбинированной вакциной против гепатита A и B.
Вакцинация против гепатита B возможна в любом возрасте, включая новорождённых.
hepatitis_b.protection: Помимо вакцинации, следует избегать рискованного поведения, такого как незащищённый секс и контакт с кровью, а также обеспечивать хорошую гигиену при медицинских и косметических процедурах.
occurrence: Гепатит B широко распространён в больших частях мира.
ВОЗ оценивала, что около 257 миллионов людей во всём мире жили с хроническим гепатитом B в 2017 году.
Вирус содержится в крови и других биологических жидкостях и может выживать вне тела в течение нескольких дней.
Даже небольшие количества крови могут передавать инфекцию.
source: Незащищённый секс.
Контакт с кровью, например при авариях, медицинских или стоматологических посещениях, переливаниях крови или контактных видах спорта.
Пирсинг и татуировки нестерильными инструментами.
Употребление наркотиков через инъекции.
Контакт между маленькими детьми через укусы, царапины или раны.
Передача от матери к ребёнку во время беременности или родов.
Обычный бытовой контакт.

diphtheria.title: Дифтерия
diphtheria.description: Дифтерия — бактериальная инфекция. Токсин, производимый бактериями, может повредить нервы и сердечную мышцу. Комбинированные вакцины, которые также защищают от дифтерии, входят в национальную программу вакцинации детей.
what_is: Дифтерия — заразное заболевание, которое обычно распространяется при кашле и чихании.
Если у инфицированного человека есть кожная инфекция, заболевание также может распространяться при прямом контакте с ранами.
Симптомы дифтерии включают температуру и боль в горле.
При тяжелой инфекции в горле могут появляться толстые серо-белые налёты, а также увеличенные и болезненные лимфатические узлы на шее.
Бактерия дифтерии производит токсин, который может вызвать серьёзные осложнения, влияя на сердце, мышцы, почки и нервы.
В тяжелых случаях заболевание может быть смертельным.
Дифтерия также может проявляться как кожная инфекция с образованием ран.
can_be_vaccinated: Вакцинация против дифтерии входит в национальную программу вакцинации детей.
Детям предлагается вакцинация в 3, 5 и 12 месяцев с ревакцинацией в 5 лет.
Последующие ревакцинации не входят в программу для детей.
Национальный институт сывороток рекомендует взрослым ревакцинацию против дифтерии и столбняка каждые 10 лет.
Ревакцинация также рекомендуется для путешествий, если последняя вакцинация была более 10 лет назад.
diphtheria.protection: Вакцинация — наиболее важная защита от дифтерии. Хорошая гигиена и избегание тесного контакта с инфицированными также снижают риск заражения.
occurrence: Дифтерия очень редка в Дании и большинстве европейских стран.
Однако заболевание всё ещё встречается в некоторых частях мира, особенно в регионах с низким охватом вакцинацией.
source: Передача через респираторные выделения, например при кашле и чихании.
Прямой контакт с ранами при кожной инфекции.

tbe.title: Клещевой Энцефалит(TBE)
tbe.description: Клещевой энцефалит — вирусное заболевание, передающееся клещами, и может вызвать серьёзное воспаление мозга.
what_is: Клещевой энцефалит (TBE) — вирусное заболевание, передающееся через укусы клещей в эндемичных районах.
Инфекция обычно происходит через несколько минут после укуса клеща через слюну клеща.
Также возможен источник заражения через употребление непастеризованного молока.
Большинство инфицированных остаются без симптомов.
Если симптомы появляются, они часто проявляются в две фазы. Первая фаза обычно наступает примерно через неделю после укуса клеща и вызывает лёгкую температуру, головную боль и значительную усталость.
Эта фаза обычно длится пару дней, и до двух третей пациентов полностью выздоравливают после неё.
После 2–10 дней без симптомов примерно у одного из трёх пациентов развивается вторая фаза с высокой температурой и симптомами со стороны центральной нервной системы.
Оценивается, что примерно у одного из десяти пациентов во второй фазе развиваются длительные или постоянные неврологические симптомы.
Клещевой энцефалит может быть опасным для жизни, но смертность относительно низкая. Заболевание наиболее тяжело протекает у пожилых людей, тогда как у детей тяжелые формы встречаются реже.
can_be_vaccinated: Клещевой энцефалит можно предотвратить с помощью вакцинации.
Вакцина не защищает от болезни Лайма или других клещевых инфекций и не предотвращает укусы клещей.
Против болезни Лайма вакцины нет.
Людям, которые находятся или путешествуют в зонах риска, следует рассмотреть вакцинацию в зависимости от степени контакта с клещами.
Поговорите с врачом, подходит ли вам вакцинация.
Вакцинация возможна для взрослых и детей старше 1 года.
После завершения серии вакцинации для поддержания защиты требуются регулярные ревакцинации.
tbe.protection: Помимо вакцинации, рекомендуется носить закрытую одежду и обувь в районах, где есть клещи, особенно в высокой траве, кустарниках и лесах. Быстрое удаление клещей может снизить риск болезни Лайма, но не предотвращает клещевой энцефалит, так как вирус передаётся в течение нескольких минут после укуса.
occurrence: В Дании клещевой энцефалит встречается в основном на Борнхольме.
Ранее было зарегистрировано несколько случаев в Северной Зеландии.
Клещевой энцефалит также встречается в странах Северной Европы, особенно в Швеции и Финляндии, а также в нескольких странах Центральной Европы, странах Балтии и России.
source: Заражение через клещей, встречающихся в природе.

mumps.title: Свинка
mumps.description: Свинка — вирусное заболевание со симптомами, включая температуру, головную боль, отсутствие аппетита и болезненное воспаление слюнных желёз под ушами с одной или обеих сторон.
what_is: Свинка — заразное вирусное заболевание.
